snippet: John R. Silber, Boston University’s longtime president, who died last week, had a theory that was ahead of its time: college football coaches hold too much power.
abstract: Analysis reflects on the passing of former Boston University president John R Silber, who believed that college football coaches held too much power, and proposed in 1972 that none of them be allowed to coach on game day; notes that his theory identified an issue in college athletics that became more pertinent, more obvious, in the four decades that followed.
lead_paragraph: John R. Silber, Boston University’s longtime president, who died last week, had a theory that was ahead of its time: college football coaches hold too much power.

headline.seo: Imagining a College Football Sideline Minus Coaches
